Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The family requires money for daily living expenses, and the mother needs to provide it
Expectation2: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation2: They notice the need to use protective equipment and follow hygiene steps more consistently.
Story: I wake up before dawn, quietly slipping out of bed so I don’t disturb my daughter. The bills on the kitchen table remind me why I can’t afford to miss a single shift. As a mother, I know I have to keep the lights on and food on the table. My job as a housekeeping cleaner is what keeps us afloat, but lately, the supervisor has been stricter about safety and hygiene protocols. I’m supposed to wear gloves, masks, and follow every step, no shortcuts. But the equipment is sometimes in short supply, and the extra time it takes means I can’t finish all my assigned rooms. If I fall behind, I risk losing hours—or worse, my job. My mind races: do I cut corners to keep up and make sure I bring home enough money, or do I follow every rule and risk being seen as too slow? The weight of both roles presses on me, and I stand in the supply closet, torn between being the provider my family needs and the responsible worker my job demands.
